data.title: That Riviera Touch (1966)
data.meta_description: Eric and Ernie decide to take a holiday to the South of France and unwittingly become mixed up with a band of jewel thieves.
data.text:
I have to admit I have some slight affection for this film which I don't fully comprehend myself. Its reputation, as with the other films Morecambe and Wise made - of failures to capture whatever essence made their tv work so successful - is largely earned. This is a failure to translate their small screen act to the big screen; but frankly that was never going to happen anyway. It would be unlikely now, impossible in the atmosphere of British filmmaking in the mid 60s.

At their best - and I don't think there are many that would argue against the fact that this is before the boys did their best work, The Morecambe and Wise Show beginning on the…

Whether you're going to enjoy this is ENTIRELY dependent on whether you find the 'work' of 'Morecambe and Wise' amusing, at minimum.

At its core, this is a lazy and stale "mistaken identity" espionage caper with nothing remotely recommendable about it. However, slapped on top of it is just about enough of the core "standards" of what you want from / love about Eric Morecambe and Ernie Wise's hugely beloved double-act:

You know the score; Morecambe (Eric Simpson here) is the more bumbling, hapless comic figure and Wise (playing Ernest Clark) the affable straight man to him. That's how they were as a team and that's how they are here.

It's not as strong as it could be and that's…
